channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Russia-Ukraine War: Russian Strikes and Naval Drills Unsettle Black Sea as U.N. Meets
item.description: The U.N. Security Council was holding an emergency meeting on the collapse of a deal that had allowed Ukraine to ship grain despite a Russian blockade. Moscow again struck granaries in the port of Odesa and the Russian Navy practiced destroying a ship in the Black Sea.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hospital staff cleaning broken glass on Wednesday at a hospital after a Russian strike in Odesa.

item.title: Israel’s Judicial Plan Crisis Grows as Air Reservists Threaten to Stop Serving
item.description: In a move that experts say could hurt Israel’s military readiness, pilots and other personnel issued a warning after Benjamin Netanyahu pressed ahead with a plan to limit judicial power.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Ronen Bergman
item.media:description: Israeli mounted riot police confront demonstrators gathering along a highway in Tel Aviv on Thursday during a protest against the government’s judicial overhaul bill.

item.title: How to Fight Canada’s Wildfires in the Era of Climate Change
item.description: Canada’s record-breaking wildfire season shows the need to shift from suppressing fires to preventing them as fires become more difficult to combat.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:description: A fire in British Columbia this week. With months left in the wildfire season more than 27 million acres of forest have burned, five times the annual average.

item.title: India Reels From Shortage of Tomatoes, a Culinary Staple
item.description: “We have stopped eating tomatoes in salad,” one shopper said, “and we are not making any tomato-based vegetable dishes.”
item.dc:creator: Hari Kumar and Mujib Mashal
item.media:description: Buying tomatoes at a vegetable market this month in Hyderabad, India.

item.title: UK By-Election Results: 1 Win and 2 Defeats for the Tories
item.description: The governing Conservatives retained Boris Johnson’s former Parliament seat in northwest London, but lost in two districts, including a sobering defeat in northern England.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: A polling station on Thursday in Uxbridge, west London, on the day of by-elections, which take place when a seat in the House of Commons becomes vacant between general elections.

item.title: Only Early Birds Will See Acropolis as Workers Strike Over Heat
item.description: Security guards and others say the extreme temperatures in Athens and at other historical sites are dangerous for them and for tourists. The employees are stopping work at noon at least for now.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: Tourists at the Acropolis in Athens on Thursday.

item.title: 4 Takeaways From Britain’s By-Elections
item.description: Among the takeaways from the vote, which saw two losses for Conservatives but also one win, was that Prime Minister Rishi Sunak is down but not out.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle and Mark Landler
item.media:description: Mr. Sunak with Steve Tuckwell, the newly elected conservative member of Parliament, on Friday in Ruislip, England.

item.title: Israel Is Divided by a Debate Over the Supreme Court’s Reach
item.description: The legal concept of “reasonableness,” which has allowed the Supreme Court to strike down ministerial appointments, among other things, is at the center of a domestic crisis gripping the country.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Judges on Israel’s Supreme Court in Jerusalem in January. The government is trying to rein in the power of the court.

item.title: Amsterdam to Bar Cruise Ships From Central Terminal
item.description: The Dutch capital will stop cruise ships from docking in the city center as part of a campaign to curb pollution and reduce the flow of tourists.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: A cruise ship at the passenger terminal in central Amsterdam last year.

item.title: Chinguamiga Was Born in Korea, but Shines in Mexico
item.description: Fleeing the strictures of modern life in a hypercompetitive South Korea, a young woman found a calmer way of life in Mexico — and millions of social media followers.
item.dc:creator: Elda Cantú and Marian Carrasquero
item.media:credit: Marian Carrasquero for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Mexico, the growing interest in all things Korean has made SuJin Kim a social-media sensation with more than 24 million followers on TikTok.

item.title: Around the Globe, Searing Heat With No Sign of Relief
item.description: In Asia, Europe and the United States, records are shattering, and forecasters say there’s no respite in sight.
item.dc:creator: Gerry Mullany, Delger Erdenesanaa and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Socrates Baltagiannis/Picture Alliance, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Members of the Red Cross handing out water near the Acropolis in Athens on Friday.

item.title: Spain’s Election Puts Focus on Leading Parties’ Allies
item.description: Before voting Sunday, a focus on the leading parties’ allies has dominated the campaign — and obscured debate about more fundamental issues.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: Polls suggest that Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez, Spain’s Socialist leader, may be ousted by conservatives on Sunday.

item.title: Mariupol State University Holds Graduation at Its Campus in Exile
item.description: Mariupol State University, an oasis amid the war, has graduated its newest class, more than a year after fleeing its devastated home city.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Valeriya Tkachenko continued her studies in ecology and education, even as her husband, Vladislav, underwent treatment and rehabilitation after losing a leg in the battle for Azovstal.

item.title: Stranded in Tunisia, Migrants Wait for Death
item.description: Tunisia has pushed African migrants to scorching no-man’s lands along its borders with little food and water. Under a deal with the European Union, Tunisia agreed to tighten border controls in exchange for aid.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sudanese migrants at a park in Sfax, Tunisia, in May. The Tunisian authorities have moved many African migrants out of Sfax and brought them to the desert near the Libyan border.

item.title: Four Charged in Gold Coin Theft From German Museum
item.description: The arrests came about eight months after thieves cut fiber optic cables, broke into a museum in Bavaria and stole 483 ancient gold coins, the police said.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Police officers search for evidence related to the theft of gold coins on a private property in Plate, Germany.

item.title: Russia Ending Ukraine Grain Deal Could Upend Food Security in Africa
item.description: Somalia, Ethiopia and others in the Horn of Africa could be hit the hardest, a leader of an aid group said.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:description: A worker preparing baked goods with wheat from Ukraine at a bakery in Mogadishu, Somalia, on Sunday.

item.title: What to Read to Understand the Unrest in France
item.description: Severe protests have roiled France in recent weeks, after a police officer fatally shot a French teenager of Algerian and Moroccan descent in a suburb of Paris. The demonstrations fit a longstanding pattern.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: Protesters at a memorial march for Nahel Merzouk, who was killed by a police officer last month in Nanterre, France.

item.title: Russia Detains Igor Girkin, a Critic of Putin’s War Effort in Ukraine: What to Know
item.description: The arrest was a sign that Russia was clamping down further on dissent, even among prominent nationalists, after last month’s brief mutiny by Wagner mercenaries.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Igor Girkin, also known as Strelkov, in Moscow in 2022.

item.title: Why Is Switzerland — of All Places — Importing So Much Cheese?
item.description: The cheese-proud country has recently imported more of the stuff than it exports, a worry for farmers and traditionalists.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: Gruyère cheese at a production facility in Bulle, Switzerland. The country has recently been importing more cheese than it exports.

item.title: Mariupol State University has graduated its newest class after fleeing its devastated home city.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins

item.title: From an Ancient Soil Sample, Clues to An Ice Sheet’s Future
item.description: A rediscovered sample of frozen sediment, collected more than 50 years ago, highlights the vulnerability of Greenland’s ice sheet to a warming climate.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.media:description: The Greenland ice sheet. An analysis of long-lost soil samples from beneath the sheet suggest that the area was ice-free 400,000 years ago.

item.title: Why Do Australian Politicians Love Nicknames?
item.description: To the average voter, ScoMo might sound more comfortable than “Prime Minister Morrison.”
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Supporters of Anthony Albanese during election night in Sydney, Australia, last year.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Russian attacks on Ukraine’s ports.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Ukrainians evacuated with their belongings following a Russian attack on the port city of Odesa.

item.title: CIA Chief Says Wagner Mutiny Revived Questions About Putin’s Rule
item.description: William J. Burns gave the most detailed public account yet by a U.S. official of the damage done to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia by last month’s uprising by the mercenary group.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and David E. Sanger
item.media:description: The director of the Central Intelligence Agency, William J. Burns, in Washington in March.

item.title: Russia Steps Up Strikes on Ukraine Grain Ports as U.S. Warns of Ship Attacks
item.description: A White House official said Moscow might stage an attack on a commercial ship and blame Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear, Neil MacFarquhar and James C. McKinley Jr.
item.media:description: Rescue workers at the site of a building destroyed in a Russian attack in Odesa, Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: The First Wins in the Women’s World Cup
item.description: Also, tensions between Iraq and Sweden and a gathering of golden retrievers.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: urora Mikalsen of Norway showing dejection after allowing the first goal to Hannah Wilkinson of New Zealand during the FIFA Women’s World Cup Australia & New Zealand 2023 Group A match.

item.title: Grain Prices Rise After Russia Terminates Ukraine Export Deal
item.description: Moscow terminated a deal this week that allowing Ukraine to export its food crops, an agreement that had helped to stabilize grain prices and to ease a global food shortage.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A worker at a grain processing facility near Lviv, Ukraine, last year. The U.N. Food and Agriculture Organization said Afghanistan, Yemen, South Sudan, Central African Republic, Liberia and Haiti will be impacted.

item.title: ‘Lioness’ Spotted in Germany Was Probably a Wild Boar, Officials Say
item.description: Repeated sightings of what some believed was a large cat near Berlin had prompted concern. The authorities later said that a search did not turn up what they were expecting.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor and Melina Delkic
item.media:description: Michael Grubert, the mayor of Kleinmachnow, Germany, holds a picture of what had been thought to be a lion, but which officials said on Friday was likely to be a wild boar.

item.title: Biden’s ‘Justice40’ Program Won’t Fix Racial Gap in Air Quality, Study Finds
item.description: The White House aimed for a race-neutral environmental justice strategy, but a new analysis questions whether the program can actually achieve its goals.
item.dc:creator: Delger Erdenesanaa
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Homes around a Valero refinery near the Houston Ship Channel.

item.title: Antigovernment Protests in Kenya Leave Several Dead and Streets in Chaos
item.description: Antigovernment protests over price hikes and new taxes have left at least 31 people dead in recent weeks, prompting the country’s news outlets to join together to issue a dire warning.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:description: An opposition supporter clashing with police in Nairobi, Kenya, on Thursday during an anti-government protest against soaring food and fuel prices and steep tax hikes.

item.title: What Russia’s Grain Deal Actions Mean for Ukraine
item.description: Moscow withdrew from a deal that allowed Ukraine to export grain across the Black Sea despite a wartime blockade, and warned that ships sailing around Ukrainian ports would be seen as military targets.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Grain is stored in the town of Kushuhum in Ukraine’s southern Zaporizhzhia region.

item.title: Europe Embraces the Siesta to Deal With the Intense Heat Wave
item.description: The siesta, a sacred afternoon break in Spain, was once mocked as lazy. But now, countries like Germany, which were among the siesta haters, are taking another look.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: The siesta, Spain’s famed afternoon break, is gaining traction in other European countries like Germany.

item.title: Ukraine Starts Using U.S.-Made Cluster Munitions, Officials Say
item.description: The weapons are being used in the southeast, the officials say.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cluster munitions found by a farmer near Siversk, Ukraine, last year.

item.title: For Europe’s Older Population, Heat Is the New Covid
item.description: Scorching temperatures have threatened the health of the elderly and pushed them inside, while governments are trying to take extraordinary steps to protect them.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:credit: Alessandro Penso for The New York Times
item.media:description: Donata Grillo, 75, cooled herself with a damp sponge on Wednesday in Rome, where she lives alone without air conditioning or a functioning refrigerator.

item.title: Investor Charged With Kidnapping ‘Crypto King’
item.description: Aiden Pleterski is accused of spending investors’ money on luxury cars and vacations before filing for bankruptcy, according to court records. Then he was kidnapped by one of his investors, police say.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez
item.media:description: Aiden Pleterski was beaten by his kidnappers, court records said.

item.title: Landslide Triggered By Rain Kills At Least 10 in Western India
item.description: More than 100 more people were feared to be trapped under debris, as torrential monsoon rainfall continued to pummel the country.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir and Hari Kumar
item.media:description: Rescue workers at the site of a landslide in Maharashtra State, India, on Thursday.

item.title: Wagner Fighters Are Training Troops on the Border With Poland, Belarus Says
item.description: The Belarusian Defense Ministry said the country’s special operations units were jointly training with Wagner at a military range near the city of Brest.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Recently erected tents at a military base near Asipovichy, Belarus.

item.title: What Will Happen to Pvt. Travis T. King in North Korea?
item.description: It may take days or weeks for the country to acknowledge that it has Pvt. Travis T. King in custody, and past practices suggest its response will be determined by Mr. King’s motive.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Morry Gash/Family Photo, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Private King bolted into North Korea while on a tour of the Demilitarized Zone on Tuesday, a day after he was supposed to travel to a base in the U.S. to face punishment.

item.title: Kissinger Meets Xi as China Courts ‘Old Friends’ to Manage U.S. Rivalry
item.description: In meeting with Henry Kissinger, China’s leader, Xi Jinping, is turning to American contacts outside the Biden administration to try to influence Washington’s thinking on China.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson, Vivian Wang and Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Cns, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: China’s President Xi Jinping speaking with the former U.S. Secretary of State Henry Kissinger in Beijing on Thursday.

item.title: Viral Video of Sexual Assault in India Renews Attention on Manipur
item.description: The attack on two women in the state of Manipur led to the first public comments from Prime Minister Narendra Modi, however indirect, about the monthslong violence in the state.
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj
item.media:description: A demonstration demanding the restoration of peace in the Indian state of Manipur, in Imphal, on Monday.

item.title: British By-elections: What to Know
item.description: Three seats in Parliament recently occupied by Conservatives are up for grabs in an election that may show which way the political winds are blowing.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Expectations in the British by-elections for the Conservatives are so low that even winning one contest would be a welcome relief for Prime Minister Rishi Sunak.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: China pushes back against U.S. climate pressure.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: China’s leader, Xi Jinping, visiting a coal yard of a company in northwestern China’s Shanxi Province last year.

item.title: Ukrainian Children With Cancer Fight Their Own War Within a War
item.description: The war with Russia compounds the struggles of pediatric cancer patients and their families, but it has also prompted positive changes in treatment in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mykola, born a month before the Russian invasion last year, in a playroom at Ohmatdyt Children’s Hospital in Kyiv, in June.

item.title: Archaeologists Find Maya City in an ‘Empty Zone’ of the Yucatán Map
item.description: In a biological preserve in Mexico’s Campeche State, a team of archaeologists has documented pyramids, palaces, a ball court and other remains of an ancient city they call Ocomtún.
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas

item.title: Theme Park’s Selective History Appeals to a New Spanish Nationalism
item.description: Puy du Fou España has drawn visitors with spectacular shows about Spanish history. But part of its success lies in what goes unsaid.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: Performances at Puy du Fou España in Toledo gloss over or ignore some more questionable aspects of Spain’s past.

item.title: Swedish Embassy in Baghdad Is Set on Fire
item.description: The demonstrators, responding to a protest in Stockholm last month and ahead of one on Thursday, set fire to parts of the building.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai and Raja Abdulrahim

item.title: Russia Hits Grain Ports in Odesa and Threatens Ships Headed to Ukraine
item.description: Ukraine accused Moscow of specifically targeting the infrastructure for exporting food, after Russia pulled out of an agreement allowing ships carrying grain to sail past its Black Sea blockade.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Joe Rennison
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hospital staff cleaning broken glass at the regional oncological dispensary hospital, following a Russian strike in Odesa on Wednesday. It was the second straight night of concentrated attacks on Odesa, Ukraine’s largest port, and other shipping centers.

item.title: Auckland Shooting: 2 Killed in New Zealand as World Cup Is Set to Begin
item.description: There were also multiple injuries, the police said, and the 24-year-old gunman was also killed. The shooting was not far from where Norway’s national team is staying for the Women’s World Cup.
item.dc:creator: Juliet Macur, Andrew Das and Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: An armed New Zealand police officer stands at a roadblock in the central business district following a shooting in Auckland, New Zealand, Thursday morning.

item.title: Morocco Invites Netanyahu to Visit, in a Possible Opening to Deeper Ties
item.description: The invitation came in a letter from King Mohammed VI to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel thanking him for recognizing Moroccan sovereignty over Western Sahara.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel during a Knesset meeting in Jerusalem earlier this month.

item.title: U.S. to Send $1.3 Billion in Ukraine Aid, Bringing Total This Week to $2.3 Billion
item.description: The money is expected to be used to buy new air-defense missile systems and other military equipment.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Spanish soldiers preparing a rocket launcher at the Lielvarde air base in Latvia in March.

item.title: What Russians saw on TV: The traitor and the ‘indisputable hero.’
item.description: Viewers of state media were told that a mutiny and other events are causes for celebration.
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas

item.title: Egypt Pardons Patrick Zaki and Mohamed el-Baqer
item.description: One of the presidential pardons came just a day after a graduate student was sentenced to three years for writing an article critical of the government.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Patrick Zaki arriving for a hearing in Mansoura, Egypt, last year.

item.title: Global Warming Is Bringing More Change Than Just Heat
item.description: Climate change is already affecting the world in powerful ways. But it could also drive mass migration and reshape societies as its consequences add up.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: The wreckage in Fort Myers Beach, Fla., after Hurricane Ian last fall. Climate displacement is not limited to crossing international borders.

item.title: UK’s MI6 Chief Says Putin Cut a Deal to End Wagner Revolt
item.description: Richard Moore, the chief of MI6, said the Russian leader acted “to save his skin,” offering rare insights into the events surrounding the sudden end of Yevgeny V. Prigozhin’s march on Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: Richard Moore, the leader of Britain’s MI6 intelligence agency, speaking in London in November 2022. On Wednesday in Prague, he offered rare insights into the brief mercenary rebellion against Russia’s military leadership last month.

item.title: Here’s Where Global Heat Records Stand So Far in July
item.description: Average temperatures for the entire globe have been at their highest on record, scientists said.
item.dc:creator: Elena Shao

item.title: Why Odesa Is So Important to Ukraine in the War With Russia
item.description: Russia’s withdrawal from a U.N.-backed grain deal and its attacks on Odesa have brought the Black Sea port city’s importance back into focus.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Odesa, Ukraine, last year. The port city is Ukraine’s window to the Black Sea, and a gateway for grain that feeds people around the world.

item.title: Dermot Doran, Priest Who Rallied Aid for Biafran Airlift, Dies at 88
item.description: In 1968, Father Doran, who had been in Nigeria as an educator, became the linchpin of one of the largest civilian humanitarian efforts in history.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen

item.title: Is Seeing ‘Barbie’ or ‘Oppenheimer’ Like Crossing a Picket Line? Unions Say No
item.description: People sympathetic with the strikers may be concerned, but the actors’ and writers’ unions say it’s OK to go to the movies and use streaming services.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Warner Bros Pictures/Universal Pictures, via Associated Press
item.media:description: With excitement swirling around the premieres of “Barbie” and “Oppenheimer” on Friday, some moviegoers are wondering whether they should reconsider amid actors’ and writers’ strikes.

item.title: 1898: Riots in Shanghai Are Now Subsiding
item.description: Sailors remained on guard at the French settlement after violence in which 22 Chinese people were killed and 50 others wounded.
item.dc:creator: The International Herald Tribune

item.title: She’s on a Mission From God: Suing Big Oil for Climate Damages
item.description: A lawyer started small with a creative tactic. It grew into an effort that could force fossil fuel companies to pay hundreds of billions in damages.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles and Erin Schaff
item.category: Milberg Coleman Bryson Phillips Grossman PLLC
item.media:description: Missy Sims, a lawyer with Milberg, one of the biggest class-action firms in the world, at a cemetery in Lares, P.R.

item.title: Protests Simmer in Israel as Country’s President Prepares to Address Congress
item.description: The small protests reflect the broad nature of popular opposition to plans by Israel’s government to overhaul the judiciary, and seemed timed to coincide with the speech by President Isaac Herzog.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Protesters against proposed judicial changes marching in Tel Aviv on Tuesday.
